data.text: We usually have a lightweight tarp with us. When we make camp, the first thing we do is set up the tarp, so that we have somewhere sheltered to work under. Then we set up the tent under the tarp, so the inner doesn't get wet, and then move it out into the rain so that you step in and out of it under the tarp. This gives us a sheltered outdoor area to cook or store our stuff. There's also something to be said for keeping components greased/lubed.

data.text: Find a pub if it‚Äôs that badüòÇ There‚Äôs not much on a modern bike that‚Äôll rust really besides the chain and maybe a bit of surface rust on the brake rotors. It‚Äôll take more than a few days for stainless gear cables to rust too. Pretty much every ride between September & May where I live is wet. I regularly put the bike away wet, in a cold damp shed until the next weekend. As long as I dry & oil the chain it‚Äôs no problem. Even if I don‚Äôt & come back a week later to an orange chain, a quick oil and a few turns of the cranks & it‚Äôs fine again. Any surface rust patches on the stainless rotors disappears the first time I pull the brakes. Even if you have a steel frame I wouldn‚Äôt worry. It takes many years in a very wet / humid environment for rust inside the tubes to become a problem, not worth worrying about. Just pack a micro fibre cloth and a little bottle of wet lube for the chain, wouldn‚Äôt bother with the faff of covering the bike. No rust that can form in a day or two will be deep enough to cause any problems.

data.text: Mostly all I do is wash the bike (particularly if on dirt roads), and lube the chain, after a wet ride, as light corrosion will appear in 1-2weeks. Intermittently will also lube all the other easily accessible moving parts. I keep the bikes indoors and so will dry out that day. The biggest thing I have noticed over the years is that the bikes I have stored indoors, deteriorate a lot less than the outdoor stored bike, particularly with cables, tyres (rain, sun). As per another post I recently rediscovered my dad‚Äôs steel bike that had been hanging in our garage for 40years (dry inland conditions). It was in great condition and after a clean and replacing one of four cables, some cable adjustments, and lots of lube everywhere was good to ride again
